entry.title: How I Added Custom Datadog Metrics using an Unsupported Language.

link.title: How I Added Custom Datadog Metrics using an Unsupported Language.

entry.content:
First, let me address the elephant in the room: OpenTelemetry. Yes, Iâ€™m aware of the protocol, and my team could have used it. But due to some limiting factors, it wasnâ€™t an option for us.

We tried it before and ran into issues. This was before I owned the project, so I donâ€™t know all the specifics. Our DevOps team advised against it due to constraints within our organizationâ€™s Datadog setup. So, we needed an alternativeâ€”and I built one.

Context

My team was told that our existing monitoring tools would no longer be supported due to expiring contracts and a company-wide push to use Datadog instead of Grafana/Sentry. Honestly, I didnâ€™t mind; I like Datadog a lot. Iâ€™ve used it in contract work and personal projects. But our team capacity was limited. Weâ€™d just lost both of our SMEs for monitoring/observability, we had a high-priority project that was already behind, and the clock was ticking on our expiring tools.

My manager asked, â€œCan you do this?â€

Fresh off a large cross-team project Iâ€™d led, I was ready for something that would help my team and require a bit of creativity. This project had it all:

A looming deadline. A clear high-level problem, but no technical requirements. The need for metrics to appear in Datadog, but no official support for Elixir, and OpenTelemetry wasnâ€™t an option. I was in. Letâ€™s do this.

What is DogStatsD?

After some research, I discovered that Datadog provides a way to receive custom application metrics: DogStatsD.

DogStatsD Overview DogStatsD is Datadogâ€™s custom implementation of the StatsD protocol, designed to collect and aggregate application metrics. It works by having your application send metrics over UDP to a local Datadog Agent, which then forwards them to Datadogâ€™s backend for visualization and alerting.

The beauty of DogStatsD is its simplicity and performance: UDP is fast and non-blocking, so your application can fire off metrics without waiting for a response. Plus, DogStatsD supports advanced features like tags, service checks, and events, making it a powerful tool for custom monitoringâ€”even if your language isnâ€™t officially supported.

So, communicating with Datadog was possibleâ€”I just needed to give our application the ability to do so. My solution started to take shape:

Connect to the Datadog agent. Create an adaptor to translate metrics into the format Datadog expects. Add metric calls to our business logic. Connecting to Datadog Using Statix I decided to use the Statix library, which allows you to write directly to a Datadog StatsD server. The default host and port can be found in the library documentation.

First, start up the connection in application.ex:


# application.ex
def start(_type, _args) do
  :ok = MyApplication.Metrics.DatadogAdaptor.connect()
  ...
end

And configure Statix in config.ex:


# config.ex
config :statix,
  prefix: "sample",
  host: "YOUR_DATADOG_HOST",
  port: YOUR_DATADOG_PORT

To use the library, simply call use in your adaptor module:

# DatadogAdaptor.ex
defmodule Metrics.DatadogAdaptor do
  use Statix, runtime_config: true
end

The Implementation

This is the fun partâ€”where I actually get to code, not just follow instructions.

I decided to use the Adapter Design Pattern. This was our teamâ€™s first adapter, but it set a precedent for future projects. (I may write a post just about adapters later.) In short, itâ€™s a middleman layer that allows the application to interact with an otherwise incompatible interface. It also creates a single point for logic, making future changes modular and manageable.

Datadog Tags and Phoenix Plugs If youâ€™re not familiar with Datadogâ€™s dashboard, I love how simple the filters and pages are. Datadog uses tags to filter dashboards, monitoring, APM, etc.â€”a very streamlined approach. For our application, we had agreed-upon required tags for each metric (I called these â€œglobal tagsâ€), plus process-specific tags unique to each request.

Luckily, Phoenix (Elixirâ€™s most famous framework) has something called a [Plug]. Plugs are a middleware-like layer that lets you add logic to your applicationâ€™s request pipeline.

Plug and Pipeline Plugs are a great place to add logic thatâ€™s necessary for the service of the application but isnâ€™t business logicâ€”like monitoring. We keep plugs organized using the pipeline macro. 

# MyApp_web.Router.ex

pipeline :monitoring do
  plug(MyApp.Plug.SetMetricTags)
  #...
end

scope "/prior_auth" do
  post("/investigation", InsuranceInvestigationController, :create)
end

Since my logic isnâ€™t business logic and needs to affect every request for this endpoint, I created a plug that I can add to the pipeline:


defmodule MyApp.Plug.SetMetricTags do
  import Plug.Conn

  def init(options), do: options

  def call(conn, _options) do
    router = conn.private.phoenix_router
    request_path = conn.request_path
    method = conn.method

    %{plug: controller, plug_opts: controller_function} =
      Phoenix.Router.route_info(router, method, request_path, "")

    metric_tags = [
      "controller:#{to_string(controller)}",
      "is_test_message:#{conn.assigns[:is_test_message] || false}",
      "route:#{request_path}"
    ]

    Process.put(:metric_tags, metric_tags)
    assign(conn, :metric_tags, metric_tags)
  end
end

This adds the list of metric_tags to the process dictionary, making them globally available throughout the application. Weâ€™ll add request-specific tags when we create the metric itself.

Metric Adapter and Request-Specific Tags

Finally, the adapter. The objectives here:

  • Create the metric name.
  • Retrieve the global tags from the SetMetricTags plug.
  • Add process-specific tags and combine them with the global tags.

Since this was a first for me, my main focus was readability and clarity. Most of the devs on my team hadnâ€™t done something like this before, so it was on me to make it clear for everyoneâ€”senior, mid, and junior alike.

First, letâ€™s pull the global metrics. Datadog requires them to be a list/array of strings.

Breakdown of the Elixir Code Below If youâ€™re not familiar, this may look confusing. Elixir allows two things:
|-> Function Header Pattern Matching: You can destructure a functionâ€™s parameters directly in the header, as long as they match the expected type.
|-> Overloading: You can define multiple functions with the same name but different parameters, creating different implementations. 

# MyApp.Metrics.MetricsAdaptor

defp collect_module_tags([_ | _] = module_tags) do
  Enum.map(
    module_tags,
    fn {key, value} -> "#{key}:#{value}" end
  )
end

defp collect_module_tags([]), do: []

defp collect_module_tags(module_tags) do
  raise "Tags passed into Metrics.increment directly from the module should be a list. Attempted tags: #{module_tags}"
end

This logic combines the request-specific tags and the global tags into a single list. Next, I sanitize the metric names for uniformity:


# MyApp.Metrics.MetricsAdaptor

@spec sanitize_metric_name(term()) :: String.t()
def sanitize_metric_name(metric) when is_binary(metric) do
  String.replace(metric, " ", "_")
end

def sanitize_metric_name(metric) do
  metric
  |> inspect # Returns a binary metric name
  |> sanitize_metric_name
end

Result:

Metric Name Sanitization: Convert external request â†’ Convert_external_request Tag List: [is_test_message: true, controller: â€œ/benefit_investigationâ€] â†’ [â€œis_test_message:trueâ€, â€œcontroller:/benefit_investigationâ€] With the tags combined and metric names sanitized, weâ€™re ready to send metrics to the Datadog agent.


# Datadog.Tags.ex

def fetch do
  case Process.get(:metric_tags) do
    nil -> """
    Failed to retrieve the :metric_tags from Process Dictionary.
    """
    metric_tags -> # Catch-all
      if is_list(metric_tags), do: metric_tags, else: List.wrap(metric_tags)
  end
end

# MyApp.Metrics.MetricsAdaptor

use Statix, runtime_config: true

@doc "Increment/2 increases/adds a metric to Datadog by 1"
@spec increment(String.t(), list()) :: :ok
def increment(metric, tags \\ []) do
  datadog_tags = Tags.fetch() ++ collect_module_tags(tags)
  Statix.increment(metric, 1, tags: datadog_tags)
end

Now, I just need to call the increment/2 function in my business logic andâ€”boom!â€”the metric appears in Datadog. I canâ€™t show our business logic, but when Iâ€™m done with my side project (which uses a similar implementation), Iâ€™ll add screenshots below.

Example of the finished product in Datadog:

What Would I Change? (And an Idea)

Iâ€™m not a fan of calling Metric.increment directly within business logic. I know, weâ€™re starting to wade into Elixir/Functionalâ€™s â€œno side effectsâ€ territory! Allow me a quick soapbox moment: side effects are only a problem when theyâ€™re hidden and untraceable. By keeping them minimal and well-documented, itâ€™s manageable.

That said, I had an idea: a decorator-like implementation that watches for certain logic and then triggers the Metric.increment call. Thereâ€™s a lot to figure out, but maybe a library or something similar could combine aspect-oriented programming, OpenTelemetry, and some kind of event watcher. I think it could be really useful.

entry.title: Persistence Over Perfection, My Journey to Software Engineering

link.title: Persistence Over Perfection, My Journey to Software Engineering

entry.content:
If thereâ€™s one thing Iâ€™ve learned about myself, itâ€™s that I rarely do things the â€œnormalâ€ way. While everyone else was busy racking up points in the Accelerated Reading program with the usual suspectsâ€”Magic Tree House, Diary of a Wimpy Kid, Harry Potterâ€”I was more interested in hacking my way through Deus Ex Machina: Human Evolution or setting my alarm for 4 a.m. to catch Cowboy Bebop reruns. Iâ€™ve always had a knack for finding my own path, especially when the standard route just didnâ€™t make sense to me.

Letâ€™s rewind a bit. In elementary school, my reading scores were so low that my teachers wanted to hold me back a year. The school had this AR program where you had to rack up points by reading certain books. Magic Tree House? Diary of a Wimpy Kid? Harry Potter? Sorry, not for me. I wanted something with a little more edge. My teacher, probably at her witâ€™s end, finally just let me loose in the library. â€œPick anything,â€ she said. I came back with a Tom Clancy novelâ€”four reading levels above where I was â€œsupposedâ€ to be. Political intrigue, shadow governments, the threat of World War III. Now that was a story. By the time they scrapped the AR program, I had one of the highest point totals in the school.

Fast forward to high school, and I was the kid who set his alarm for 4 a.m. just to watch anime that wasnâ€™t even meant for my age group. Iâ€™d do my homework while the rest of the house slept, then make sure everyone else was up for school and work. I guess you could say Iâ€™ve always been a littleâ€¦ unconventional.

When I started college in 2012, I was working 40 hours a week and going to school full-time. At first, I tried to do it allâ€”show up to every class, ace every test, be the model student. Spoiler: I was burning out fast. So I did what I do bestâ€”I changed my approach. I mapped out the labs, test days, and project deadlines, and focused my energy there. Suddenly, my grades improved and I actually had time to sleep. Who knew?

So when it came time to break into tech, I knew the â€œtraditionalâ€ path wasnâ€™t for me. I wasnâ€™t about to take on more debt for a CS degree, and bootcamps felt like a stress marathon. I figured, if I could teach myself how to survive college and work, I could teach myself to code. I just needed a plan, some mentors, and a place where I could learn from my mistakes.

Hereâ€™s how I mapped it out (with a little help from Disneyâ€™s funniest meme-worthy character):

  • Get a jobâ€”any jobâ€”in a tech company.
  • Find a mentor who actually knows what theyâ€™re doing.
  • Learn to code, then learn to program, then learn to build real applications.
  • Build a resume with actual projects, not just certificates.

Rolling the Dice: Getting My Foot in the Door

My first â€œtechâ€ job? Office worker at a healthcare/pharma tech company in my hometown. The company helped doctors and patients with prescription authorizations, and letâ€™s just say, a lot of those authorizations failed because of missing data. (Iâ€™ll skip the interview story, but letâ€™s just say I rolled a Nat 20 on my persuasion check.)

The real challenge was moving from the call center to anything even remotely related to software. Meanwhile, I was teaching myself Java (my first language), then Python, and figuring out Django. I was basically building my own curriculum, one Google search at a time.

Then, I got picked for a test group at work. We were supposed to try a new workflow for prior authorizationsâ€”call the pharmacy first, not the insurance company. By the end of the quarter, I was leading the project, reporting to leadership, learning SQL, and even suggesting ways to improve our workflow. Not bad for a guy who started out answering phones.

Mentorship: The Game Changer

Enter Dan, my mentor. If it wasnâ€™t for him, I probably wouldâ€™ve stalled out after the test group project. The company had this stretch program for aspiring software engineers. Most people went back to their day jobs, but a few of us got a shot at an apprenticeship. Danâ€™s advice? Stop doing tutorials. Stop just reading textbooks.

Write code, write code badly. Figure out why itâ€™s bad. Write it again, but better. So I did. I built a web scraper, a D&D manager, and a bunch of other projects in Python. When it came time to apply for the program, I knew the competition would be tough. Three interviews, three teams, three different sets of expectations. The program was new, so every interview was a little different, but they all wanted to see if you could actually build something.

Facing My Weaknesses: The Front-End Challenge

The first interview? Full-stack team, but with a front-end focusâ€”specifically Vue.js. At that point, my front-end experience was basically â€œI know what a button looks like.â€ Iâ€™d spent most of my time on backend projects, so JavaScript frameworks and dynamic UIs were a whole new world.

They gave me some sample code to review and asked me questions about it. I could walk through the code and explain what it was doing, but when they asked about my own experience or real-world front-end projects, I didnâ€™t have much to say. I realized pretty quickly that while I could reason through code, I didnâ€™t have the hands-on experience that comes from actually building and debugging front-end apps.

It was humbling, for sure. My backend skills werenâ€™t enough to carry me through a full-stack interviewâ€”especially when the team wanted someone comfortable with Vue.js and modern JavaScript. I didnâ€™t get negative feedback, but it was clear my lack of front-end experience was a gap.

But hereâ€™s the thing: I didnâ€™t let it get me down. After the interview, I added JavaScript and Vue.js to my â€œto-learnâ€ list. I started exploring tutorials, building small projects, and messing around with component-based development. Even though I eventually decided to focus more on backend, that experience taught me the importance of being adaptable and willing to step outside my comfort zone.

Looking back, Iâ€™m actually grateful for that interview. It showed me a weakness, but it also gave me a clear direction for growth. In tech, thereâ€™s always something new to learnâ€”and thatâ€™s half the fun.

Finding My Groove with Ruby

The second interview was for a full-stack team using Ruby on Rails. Since I had Python experience, Ruby wasnâ€™t a big stretch. I explained my D&D project and how I built it. I thought I was out of the running, but then another manager, Matt, reached out for an interview.

Matt focused on my motivations and how I planned to teach myself. â€œThis program is simply a mentorship. You will be teaching yourself most of the time.â€

I started with his team, working two days a week with two mentors. I began with Codecademyâ€™s Ruby courses, then moved on to small challenges. I needed to complete a final project to be evaluated.

At first, I struggled. During pair sessions, I didnâ€™t understand the â€œmagicâ€ of Ruby, which made debugging harder. My mentor was direct: â€œWe are expecting you to perform better than this.â€ Some of the feedback:

Better test cases: Test the logic, think of real-world situations, invalid inputs, and unexpected code. Better debugging: Use debugging tools, not just print statements. Find the root cause, not just the symptoms. That weekend, I took a hard look at myself. I didnâ€™t want to go back to the call center. If I was behind, I needed a plan to catch up.

That Tuesday, I called a meeting with my manager and mentors: â€œIâ€™d like to change our approach. I got some feedback, and I think this is how I can not only fix my issues but actually become a better developer if weâ€¦â€

My new approach:

A small project every week Write test cases for every challenge/kata Drive during pair sessions, with mentors only helping when Iâ€™m stuck I improved, but the news of my shift to backend made me think that I was still behind.

The Mastermind Challenge: My Capstone Project

For the final project, we chose the Mastermind game from The Odin Project. Requirements included:

Bot option Player vs. player mode Login screen Display previous guesses During the presentation, a bug appeared: the login screen would reappear when the user chose player vs. player, causing a loop. I didnâ€™t realize at the time, but in the chat, I was told to just display the bot walkthrough.

I assumed everyone was troubleshooting during their presentations, so I went for it. I started by replicating another controller/integration test Iâ€™d created for player vs. player. The login information was supposed to set the sessionâ€™s ID, but I realized there was some carryover from a previous test. I removed it and suddenly, the test failed. I checked the controller fileâ€”it was misconfigured. The session wasnâ€™t being set before calling the player vs. player option, which routed back to the login page. A quick Stack Overflow search helped me set the session correctly. The login loop disappeared, and the app worked.

After the presentation, I was sent back to the call center for the rest of the week, and the program ended. I reached out to Matt for feedback and advice on my resume. For me, this experience cemented my decision: this is what I want to do, at this company or another.

Matt told me, â€œI probably shouldnâ€™t tell you this yet, but that presentation was the interview. Weâ€™re hiring you as a junior on our team.â€

Twelve devs in the program, three spots. In the end, I earned one of those spots and officially became a software engineer that yearâ€”four years ago.

Growth, Grit, and What Comes Next

The hardest part of my journey? Learning to communicate problems and solutions using developer vocabulary. The moment I realized I was in troubleâ€”not meeting my mentorâ€™s expectationsâ€”was also the moment Iâ€™m most proud of. I used introspection and persistence to improve.

My advice: Learn to code, learn to write programs, then build side projects. Stick to one language until youâ€™re comfortable.

My current goals: Iâ€™m looking for a job I can be passionate about, where I can help others. Iâ€™m also working on a TTRPG site that allows players and GMs to play any tabletop game online.

If youâ€™re on an unconventional path, keep going. Persistence and adaptability are your best tools. And if you ever feel lost, confused, or unsure of an answerâ€”whether youâ€™re behind a keyboard or just trying to figure out your next moveâ€”remember:

The process is just as important as the solution.

entry.title: How Bartending Made Me a Better Problem Solver

link.title: How Bartending Made Me a Better Problem Solver

entry.content:
I donâ€™t remember exactly when I caught the coding bug. Maybe it started when I played Skyrim with a mod that was no longer being updated, and decided to fix it myself. Or maybe it was when I picked upÂ Automate the Boring Stuff with PythonÂ and learned Python just for fun. I even learned some HTML and CSS back in high school, making a scrolling banner on a static page.

But what I do know is that Iâ€™ve always loved problem-solving and creating something for others to enjoy. The funny thing is, I didnâ€™t really become good at it until I became a bartender.

Iâ€™m forever grateful for my time as a server and bartender. The lessons I learned from meeting and talking to new people every day were invaluable. The biggest challenge? When someone would ask, â€œCan you make me a salty yet sweet drink, but not a margarita?â€ Suddenly, I had to come up with a solution on the spot for a complete stranger. Thatâ€™s a tough problemâ€”even on the slowest days.

At first, my approach was to learn everything about every spirit at the bar. Bourbon vs. scotch. Why some cocktails are shaken and others stirred. When to use Beefeater vs. Tanqueray. Sometimes this worked, but other times it was a complete failureâ€”even when I thought I understood the guestâ€™s taste. What was I missing?

â€œGive me six hours to chop down a tree and I will spend the first four sharpening the axe.â€
â€” Abraham Lincoln

I realized my process was the problem. I didnâ€™t have ten years of experience, and I was trying to be perfect on the first try. Sure, I could follow a recipe and replicate a classic drink, but that rarely impressed anyone. So, I started doing what I now do in coding: I start with the process. What steps do I need to get to a solution?

Letâ€™s go back to that â€œnot a margaritaâ€ request. Here were the requirements:

  • Refreshing (it was a hot day, and it was brunch!)
  • Tequila, but not too forward (the taste shouldnâ€™t be overpowering)
  • Still salty

So, basically a margaritaâ€”but not a margarita. I had my objectives. Next, I started building. Tequila would play a main role, but I needed to keep it balanced. Lime is an easy way to add refreshment, and if you get the balance right, it can carry the drink.

Hereâ€™s where the process comes in. Iâ€™d make enough of the drink to taste it, grab a straw, and test. This wasnâ€™t a fancy New York bar, but once I started tasting and testing my experiments, I could narrow down the solution. The guest watching me loved watching my process.

Of course, I needed a sweetener, but simple syrup would be too much. We had honey syrup, which is lighter and pairs well with tequila and lime. Another tasteâ€”getting closer, but still missing the salty component. I also wanted this drink to be a real departure from a standard margarita.

It was a hot Saturday brunch downtown, and I spotted a bottle of champagne. Sometimes, creative solutions are necessary. After shaking the spirits, I poured the cocktail into a glass, floated some champagne on top, added a pinch of salt, and finished with a lime flag. One final end-to-end taste, and I handed it to the guest for review.

She loved it. In fact, I made that drink for her every time she came in. I kept the recipe for myself, but I did share it with her before I left that job.

If you ever feel lost, confused, or unsure of an answerâ€”whether youâ€™re behind the bar or behind a keyboardâ€”I recommend looking at your process and seeing where things start to break down:

  • Do you really understand the problem?
  • Can you break it down into smaller parts?
  • Are you creating and testing solutions along the way?

Knowing the problem gets you close, but understanding and refining your process can make your solution bulletproof.

Have a good one.

entry.title: My Setup
entry.content:
My Setup and How I Use It

Iâ€™m not going to walk you through my entire setup, but I do want to highlight the stars of the show. This isnâ€™t a step-by-step guideâ€”think of it as a list of recommendations. As a self-taught dev, I picked up most of these tools while troubleshooting completely unrelated problems. Maybe theyâ€™ll help you too.

ğŸ“ Chapter 1: Note-taking & Offloading My Brain

TL;DR:Â I canâ€™t recommend Obsidian enough. I donâ€™t use it to replace my brain, just to offload some of the mental clutter.

If youâ€™ve ever dabbled in organization, project management, or even been a Game Master (iykyk), you might have heard ofÂ Obsidian. At its core, itâ€™s a note-taking appâ€”but what makes it special is its approach. Obsidian is a JavaScript-based app that stores your notes as Markdown files on your computer.

Plugins I use

I Use These in Every Vault: (Click to expand)
Dataview: |-> Think of Dataview as a way to turn your notes into a mini-database. It lets you write queries (using a simple language) to pull information from your notes and display it in tables, lists, or even as tasks. For example, you can create a table of all notes tagged with `#project` or list all tasks due this week. Itâ€™s perfect for tracking projects, tasks, or any kind of structured data.
Tasks: |-> The Tasks plugin supercharges your to-do lists in Obsidian. It lets you create, manage, and query tasks across all your notes. You can filter tasks by status, due date, or tags, and even see them in a summary view. If you like keeping your tasks close to your notes (instead of a separate app), this is a must-have.
Kanban: |-> Kanban brings Trello-style boards right into Obsidian. You can organize your projects visually, moving cards between columns like â€œTo Do,â€ â€œIn Progress,â€ and â€œDone.â€ Itâ€™s great for managing workflows, tracking progress, or just getting a birdâ€™s-eye view of what youâ€™re working onâ€”all without leaving your notes.

ğŸ›¤ï¸ Chapter 2: Alias Everything

If you work in the terminal and find yourself typing the same commands over and over, you need to start using aliases.

AnÂ aliasÂ is a shortcut for a longer or more complex command. It saves time and keystrokes. Even for simple commands, I use aliases to make my workflow smoother.

BesidesÂ git, the most commonly aliased command isÂ ls.Â Here are my favorites:

Bash

alias ll='ls -lh'   # Long format, human-readable sizes
alias la='ls -la'   # List all files, including hidden ones
alias l='ls -CF'    # List files in columns

ğŸ”¨ Chapter 3: Modern Command Line Toolkit

When I was a junior dev, I focused on mastering programming and did things the hard way for a while. Eventually, I discovered newer CLI tools that made my life so much easier. You can stick with the classics, but modern alternatives often improve on the old tools likeÂ ls,Â cd,Â grep, andÂ find.

Eza:Â A BetterÂ ls

  • Why I like it:
    • Pretty colors and syntax highlighting
    • Stack and grid layouts (eza --grid)
    • File icons (eza -l --grid --icons)
  • Docs:Â eza.rocks

FZF:Â Fuzzy Finder for Everything

Ever forget the name of a file or config?Â fzfÂ is a fuzzy finder that searches files, folders, and even command history. I stopped using Spotlight after I found this (until I discovered Raycast, but thatâ€™s another story).

Zoxide:Â SmarterÂ cd

zoxideÂ remembers your most-used directories and lets you jump to them instantly. No more typing out long pathsâ€”just typeÂ z <folder>Â and youâ€™re there.

tldr:Â Simple CLI Help

Ever see a command you donâ€™t recognize?Â tldrÂ gives you simple, community-driven explanations and examples for CLI tools. Itâ€™s like having a helpful dev friend on call.

ğŸš€ Aerospace: Simple Window Tiling Manager

If youâ€™re reading this, youâ€™re probably a power user (or on your way). Once you try a window tiling manager, you might become a fanatic like me. A tiling manager organizes your open windows into non-overlapping tiles, maximizing screen space and improving workflow.

Why use one?

  • Assign windows to workspaces and switch with hotkeys
  • Arrange windows in your preferred layout
  • Create a keyboard-driven dev experience
  • Make the most of large screens

Heads up:Â If you prefer minimal open windows, this might not be for you. But for my ADHD brain, itâ€™s a lifesaverâ€”I can keep everything open and visible, so nothing gets forgotten.

Peace out! ğŸ«¶ğŸ»

entry.title: Hello! My Name is Thomas McLean

link.title: Hello! My Name is Thomas McLean

entry.content:
I'm a self-taught full-stack developer that enjoys tackling new challenges and is known for their ability to improve quickly using introspection and problem-solving. Ask me about one of my ongoing projects. Check out some of my projects.

ğŸ“ Work

ğŸ“ Current Role

I serve as a Product/Integration Engineer, where I am involved in the entire lifecycle of product implementation, from initial brainstorming to project completion. My responsibilities encompass design, implementation, testing, and deployment, which has allowed me to gain experience with a diverse range of technologies.

ğŸ“ Key Responsibilities

My primary focus is on developing solutions that enable both internal and external stakeholders to effectively investigate insurance coverage. This includes:
  • Discovering Updated Insurance Coverage: Ensuring that users have access to the latest information regarding insurance policies.
  • Managing Prior Authorization Updates: Keeping track of changes in prior authorization requirements.
  • Identifying Drug Alternatives: Providing options for alternative medications when necessary.

Additionally, I am frequently assigned Proof of Concept (POC) projects to test market viability. If a product or feature demonstrates success, I collaborate with the team to prepare it for production and subsequently hand it off to another team for further development.

ğŸ“ Daily Insights

In my daily activities, I engage in the following tasks:
Technical Leader
Source of Technical knowledge for projects and applications. I field questions for our teams products and projects. Provide context of why future projects are important. Design project plans and timelines of work for future products. Give level design plans for Products in the Proof of concept phase.
Implementation
Translate design and concepts into functioning software systems. This includes coding, testing, integrating internal and external components to meet acceptance criteria of our products or set by our product managers.
Mentorship and Review
Assist in the growth of Junior and fellow mid level Engineers in development concepts and design patterns. Review pull request, complete risk assessments and provide retrospection for issues effecting external applications.
Cross Team/Cross Companies Communication and Assistance
Facilitate communication between teams and companies to ensure alignment on technical requirements and project goals. Assist in resolving technical issues that span multiple teams or companies, ensuring smooth collaboration and timely delivery of projects.

ğŸ“ Quarterly Insights

In my quarterly activities, I engage in the following tasks:
API Development:
Create and maintain internal APIs that facilitate data exchange between internal customers and external clients.
Front-End Development:
Build and enhance front-end applications for both internal and external users.
Technical Planning:
Develop project-specific technical requirements and establish technical standards for integrations and other projects.
Scalable Architecture Design:
Designed a scalable microservices architecture that improved system performance and reduced downtime. Led a project to optimize database queries and indexing strategies.
Product Ideation:
Deconstruct new product ideas to effectively plan and organize technical work across multiple applications.

ğŸ“ Achievements

My Recent Achievements
Gateway API Solution
My team was previously paying ~$300,000 annually for a Gateway API that enabled our application to connect to two vendors. After a cost-to-time analysis, I designed and implemented a solution that allowed our team to cancel the contract and eliminate this expense.
Application Monitoring
Leadership has directed that our team will no longer use Grafana and Sentry for monitoring applications in the future. To ensure application health, product performance, and efficient troubleshooting, I implemented logic to integrate our applications with Datadog, an observability platform.
Prior Authorization Status Check
Previously, our team spent thousands of man hours manually contacting insurance companies to update statuses on prior authorizations. I developed an API to automate the retrieval of PA statuses, significantly reducing costs. This solution supports a product that generates over ~$20 million in revenue annually and saves the company millions in expenditures.
